bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, February 6, 1922

div1.p: Barber discusses his efforts against mosquitos in Alabama.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, February 6, 1922
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Brewton, Ala. Feb. 6, 1922.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Prof. Kudo's reprint and the gorgeous epitome
of ancient and modern fiction both received. Also just got a letter
from Prof. Kudo, who makes no mention of his newspaper fame, although
I pintedly asked him if he thought his article had been misquoted.

No, I hardly think the winter attack on anophelines is promising
in this locality. It is odd where the anophelines keep themselves now.
We find a few but there ought to be more adults in a region where they
are breeding so abundantly in winter, if you could call this balmy
weather by that name. Today we are starting pig traps to see if
there are many adults around. There is certainly a lot of them
emerging. We bred out about 1500 last month-about 80% crucians, 20%
puncts. and a solitary quad. We have arsenic-treated three pools
in order to get rid of the larvae and thus perhaps find out
how soon the pools become repopulated in winter, comparing with
similar experiments done last summer. The arsenic works beautifully
in winter, s well, apparently, as in summer in this region. We are
also repeating our last winter's work on the duration of the pupal
stage in winter.

I should be very glad of any suggestions you may make as to the
best experiments to make during this season. My colleagues, Mr. Komp
and Theodore Hayne, are also would value your advice. Best of
all, come down here, to Brewton for a change of climate. Many things
in blossom in the woods besides mosquitoes.
